TEXT.Polish: Ornament (z łac. ornare - zaopatrzyć, ozdabiać) - motyw lub zespół motywów zdobniczych, stosowanych w architekturze lub sztukach plastycznych. Motywy te, złożone z drobnych elementów, mogą pokrywać całą powierzchnię, występować tylko w określonych polach albo przybierać formę pasową. Mogą także współgrać z tektoniką lub nad nią dominować. Zazwyczaj ornament nie jest elementem niezbędnym dla istnienia struktury danego przedmiotu czy budowli, a jedynie jest stosowany jako element podziału określonej kompozycji.

TEXT.English: "If one has a good disposition, what other virtue is needed? If a man has fame, what is the value of other ornamentation?" - Chanakya
TEXT.French: "Si l'on a une bonne disposition, est-ce que les autres vertues est nécessaires? Si un homme a la gloire, quelle est la valeur d'une autre décoration?" - Chanakya
TEXT.Polish: "Jeśli ktoś posiada talent to jakiej innej cnoty potrzebuje? Jeśli ktoś jest sławny to jaką wartość mają jego ornamenty?" - Chanakya

TEXT.English: TBD
Paleontology
TEXT.French: Paléontologie
TEXT.Polish: Paleontologia

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Paleontology[\BOLD] is the study of prehistoric life, including organisms' evolution and interactions with each other and their environments (their paleoecology).
TEXT.Polish: [BOLD]Paleontologia[\BOLD] dziedzina biologii zajmująca się organizmami kopalnymi, wyprowadzająca na podstawie skamieniałości i śladów działalności życiowej organizmów wnioski ogólne o życiu w przeszłości geologicznej. Ściśle związana z geologią, posługuje się często fizyką i chemią. Paleontologia skupia się bardziej na wyjasnianiu przyczyn niż na przeprowadzaniu eksperymentów i obserwowaniu skutków.

TEXT.English: "No fossil is buried with its birth certificate. That, and the scarcity of fossils, means that it is effectively impossible to link fossils into chains of cause and effect in any valid way... To take a line of fossils and claim that they represent a lineage is not a scientific hypothesis that can be tested, but an assertion that carries the same validity as a bedtime story amusing, perhaps even instructive, but not scientific." - Henry Gee, In Search of Deep Time: Beyond the Fossil Record to a New History of Life
TEXT.French: "Aucun fossile est enterré avec son certificat de naissance. Que, et la rareté des fossiles, signifie qu'il est effectivement impossible de lier fossiles dans les chaînes de cause à effet en aucune façon valable... Pour prendre une ligne de fossiles et prétendre qu'ils représentent une lignée n'est pas une hypothèse scientifique qui peut être testée, mais une affirmation qui porte la même validité que une histoire pour endormir? Amusant, peut-être même instructif, mais pas scientifique." - Henry Gee, In Search of Deep Time: Beyond the Fossil Record to a New History of Life
TEXT.Polish: “"Żadna skamieniałość nie posiada świadectwa urodzenia. To i rzadkość z jaką skamieniałości występują powoduję, że bardzo ciężko połączyć skamieniałości w jeden ciąg." - Henry Gee

TEXT.English: TBD
Panpsychism
TEXT.French: Panpsychisme

TEXT.English: In philosophy, panpsychism is the view that consciousness, mind or soul (psyche) is a universal and primordial feature of all things. Panpsychists see themselves as minds in a world of minds.

"Constantly regard the universe as one living being, having one substance and one soul; and observe how all things have reference to one perception, the perception of this one living being; and how all things act with one movement; and how all things are the cooperating causes of all things which exist; observe too the continuous spinning of the thread and the contexture of the web."[NEWLINE][SPACE] -Marcus Aurelius
TEXT.French: "Considérez constamment l'univers comme un être vivant, ayant une substance et une âme; et observez comment toutes choses se réfèrent à une seule perception, la perception de cet être vivant; et comment toutes choses agissent en un seul mouvement; et comment toutes choses sont les causes coopérantes de toutes les choses qui existent; observer aussi la rotation continue du fil et la contexture du web."[NEWLINE][SPACE] -Marcus Aurelius

TEXT.English: TBD
Papacy
TEXT.French: Papauté
TEXT.German: Papsttum
TEXT.Polish: Papiestwo

TEXT.English: The office of the pope is called the Papacy, and his ecclesiastical jurisdiction the "Holy See" or "Apostolic See". The pope is also head of state of Vatican City, a sovereign city-state entirely enclaved by the city of Rome.[PARAGRAPH:2]Early popes helped to spread Christianity and resolve doctrinal disputes. After the conversion of the rulers of the Roman Empire (the conversion of the populace was already advanced even before the Edict of Milan, 313), the Roman emperors became the popes' secular allies until, with the loss of the emperors' power in the west, Pope Stephen II was forced in the 8th century to appeal to the Franks for help, beginning a period of close interaction with the rulers of the west. For centuries, the forged Donation of Constantine also provided the basis for the papacy's claim of political supremacy over the entire former Western Roman Empire. In medieval times, popes played powerful roles in Western Europe, often struggling with monarchs for power over wide-ranging affairs of church and state, crowning emperors (Charlemagne was the first emperor crowned by a pope) and regulating disputes among secular rulers.
TEXT.Polish: Papież (Ojciec Święty) (łac. Pontifex Maximus, wł. papa, gr. pappas, forma funkcjonująca w języku polskim pochodzi od czeskiego papež) - biskup Rzymu, głowa Kościoła rzymskokatolickiego, katolickich Kościołów wschodnich, Stolicy Apostolskiej oraz państwa Watykan. Obecnym papieżem jest Benedykt XVI.

TEXT.English: "The Papacy is not other than the Ghost of the deceased Roman Empire, sitting crowned upon the grave thereof." - Thomas Hobbes
TEXT.French: "La papauté n'est autre que le fantôme du défunt Empire romain, Son trône perché sur la tombe de celui-ci." - Thomas Hobbes
TEXT.Polish: "Papież? Ile ma on dywizji?" - Józef Stalin

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Papacy[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to construct [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Apostolic Palace[COLOR_REVERT] which is required for [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Diplomatic Victory[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Papauté[COLOR_REVERT] vous permet de construire [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Le Palais Apostolique[COLOR_REVERT], nécessaire pour la [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Victoire Diplomatique[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.Spanish: El [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Pontificado[COLOR_REVERT] te permite construir el [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Palacio Apostólico[COLOR_REVERT], requerido para la [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]victoria diplomática[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Paper
TEXT.Polish: Papier

TEXT.English: When discovered, paper revolutionized information technology. Before the advent of paper, scholars and writers used a number of different materials upon which to record their words. These included clay tablets, animal skins, silk, and others. These suffered from many shortcomings. Clay was bulky and fragile, animal skins were expensive, silk was expensive and fragile, and so forth - and none of them would have been suitable for use in a printing press.[PARAGRAPH:2]Papyrus was the earliest form of paper. It was created by cutting the stem of the papyrus plant into strips, which were laid in an overlapping pattern and pounded into a sheet. The material was then dried and polished. While serviceable, the resulting sheet is fairly thick and, more importantly, subject to rot in damp climates.[PARAGRAPH:2]Paper as we know it today was invented in China in around 100 AD. Wood and other fibrous material is mixed with liquid and mashed into a pulp, which is then poured onto fine screens. The liquid drains away, leaving a thin layer of fibrous material on the wire. When this material dries, it becomes paper. The Chinese official Cai Lun is credited with adding cotton rags to the pulp; the resulting paper was far sturdier than earlier versions. The Chinese process spread slowly throughout the world, reaching Europe around 1300 AD.[PARAGRAPH:2]When paired with the printing press - yet another Chinese invention - paper exponentially increased the spread of information and art.
TEXT.French: La découverte du papier a révolutionné les techniques de l'information. Avant son invention, les érudits et les écrivains utilisaient différents supports d'écriture: tablettes d'argile, peaux de bête, soie, etc. Mais ces derniers comportaient de nombreux défauts. L'argile était encombrante et fragile, les peaux de bête coûtaient cher, la soie était fragile et onéreuse, etc. De plus, aucun de ces supports n'aurait convenu pour l'imprimerie.[PARAGRAPH:2]Le papyrus est l'ancêtre du papier. On le fabriquait en coupant la tige de la plante du même nom en fines lanières, lesquelles étaient placées les unes sur les autres en s'entrecroisant. L'ensemble était alors compressé pour former des feuilles. Ensuite, on les séchait et on appliquait un enduit. Bien que très fonctionnel, le papyrus était assez épais et surtout, avait tendance à se désagréger sous les climats humides.[PARAGRAPH:2]Le papier tel que nous le connaissons a été inventé en Chine vers l'an 100 ap. J.-C. Du bois et d'autres matières fibreuses sont mélangés à de l'eau, puis broyées pour former une pâte, qui est ensuite versée sur un tamis. Le liquide s'évacue, ne laissant sur le treillis qu'une fine couche de matière fibreuse. En séchant, cette matière devient du papier. C'est le ministre chinois Tsai Lun qui aurait ajouté des lambeaux de coton à la pâte, ce qui a permis d'obtenir un papier beaucoup plus résistant. La technique chinoise s'est ensuite répandue lentement à travers le monde et a atteint l'Europe vers 1 300 ap. J.-C.[PARAGRAPH:2]Associé à la presse typographique (autre invention chinoise), le papier a favorisé considérablement la diffusion de l'information et de l'art.
TEXT.German: Die Entwicklung des Papiers revolutionierte die Informationstechnik. Vor dem Aufkommen des Papiers verwendeten Gelehrte und Schriftsteller verschiedene andere Materialien, um ihre Worte darauf festzuhalten, wie Lehmtafeln, Tierfelle und Seide, welche aber viele Nachteile hatten. Lehm war unhandlich und zerbrechlich, Tierfelle waren teuer, Seide war teuer und empfindlich - und keines dieser Materialien wäre später für den Gebrauch in einer Druckerpresse geeignet gewesen. Die frühste Form des Papiers basierte auf dem Papyrus, einer grasartigen Pflanze. Hierzu wurde der Stamm der Pflanze in Streifen geschnitten, welche zu einem überlappenden Muster gelegt und festgestampft wurden. Das entstandene Blatt wurde dann getrocknet und geschliffen. Obwohl schon gut nutzbar, war das entstandene Blatt ziemlich dick und in feuchtem Klima anfällig für Fäulnis. Das Papier, wie wir es heute kennen, wurde etwa 100 n.Chr. in China erfunden. Holz und anderes Fasermaterial wird hierzu mit Flüssigkeit gemischt, zu einem Brei zerstampft und auf feine Laken gegossen. Nach Abfließen der Flüssigkeit bleibt eine dünne Schicht des faserigen Materials zurück, welche beim Trocknen zu Papier wird. Dem chinesischen Beamten Cai Lun wird die Idee zugeschrieben, dem Brei auch Baumwollfetzen hinzuzufügen, wodurch das entstehende Papier wesentlich haltbarer wurde. Dieses chinesische Verfahren verbreitete sich langsam in der Welt und erreichte etwa 1300 n.Chr. Europa. Mit der Erfindung des Drucks über bewegliche Schrifttypen wuchs die Bedeutung des Papiers als Medium der Informationsweitergabe rasant. Ironischerweise erschien dieses Konzept den Chinesen nicht sehr praktikabel, weil ihre Sprache zwischen 2000 und 40.000 Zeichen erfordert, und so waren es Europäer, die viel später mit Erfindung der Druckerpresse in die Geschichte eingingen.
TEXT.Italian: Quando venne scoperta, la carta rivoluzionò la tecnologia dell'informazione. Prima dell'avvento della carta, studiosi e scrittori usavano diversi tipi di materiali (tavolette d'argilla, pelli di animali, seta o altro), sui quali prendevano nota dei loro appunti, anche se nessuno di questi era indicato allo scopo. L'argilla era ingombrante e fragile, le pelli animali costavano troppo e la seta era molto cara: nessuno di questi materiali era indicato per essere usato in una pressa da stampa.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il papiro è stato la prima carta della storia: il procedimento di realizzazione consisteva nel tagliare il gambo del papiro in strisce sottili, che venivano sovrapposte una sull'altra e poi schiacciate in una specie di foglio. Il materiale veniva poi asciugato e lucidato: malgrado fosse molto utile, questa carta era spessa e tendeva a marcire nei climi umidi.[PARAGRAPH:2]La carta come la conosciamo oggi è stata inventata in Cina attorno al 100 d. C.: il legno e altri materiali fibrosi venivano mescolati con del liquido fino a ottenere una polpa, che veniva posizionata su griglie sottili. Il liquido spariva, lasciando del materiale fibroso che, una volta asciutto, diveniva la carta. Il Cai Lun ufficiale Cinese si ottiene aggiungendo all'impasto anche degli stracci; il risultato era un tipo di carta decisamente più resistente. Il procedimento Cinese si diffuse molto lentamente, raggiungendo l'Europa solamente intorno al 1300 d. C.[PARAGRAPH:2]Unitamente alla pressa da stampa, un'altra invenzione dei Cinesi, la carta divenne un veicolo fondamentale per la diffusione di informazione e arte.
TEXT.Spanish: El descubrimiento del papel revolucionó la tecnología de la información. Antes de su aparición, los eruditos y escritores empleaban diferentes materiales para poner por escrito sus palabras. Entre ellos se encontraban las tabletas de arcilla, la piel de animal, la seda y otras cosas. Estos soportes tenían numerosas desventajas. La arcilla era voluminosa y frágil, la piel de animal era cara, la seda era cara y frágil, etc... y ninguno de ellos hubiese podido emplearse con la imprenta.[PARAGRAPH:2]El papiro es la forma de papel más antigua. Se creaba cortando tiras del tallo de la planta del papiro, que a continuación se entrelazaban y se alisaban a martillazos, formando una hoja. Luego, el material se secaba y lijaba. El resultado final, aunque aprovechable, era muy grueso y, lo que es peor, susceptible a la putrefacción en climas secos.[PARAGRAPH:2]El papel tal como lo conocemos hoy en día se inventó en China alrededor del año 100 d. C. La madera y otros materiales fibrosos se mezclan con líquido y se amasan hasta quedar reducidos a una pulpa, que a continuación se extiende sobre unas pantallas finas. El líquido se escurre, dejando una fina capa de material fibroso sobre el secadero. Cuando este material se seca, se convierte en papel. Se atribuye al funcionario chino Cai Lun la idea de añadir jirones de algodón a la pulpa, haciendo mucho más resistente el papel que se obtiene. El invento chino se propagó lentamente por el mundo, y llegó a Europa en torno al año 1300 d. C.[PARAGRAPH:2]Unido a la imprenta, otro invento chino, el papel incrementó exponencialmente la capacidad de difusión de la información y la cultura.

TEXT.English: "I cannot live without books" - Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.French: "Je ne peux pas vivre sans livres." - Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.German: "Ohne Bücher kann ich nicht leben." - Thomas Jefferson (1743-1826)
TEXT.Italian: "Non potrei vivere senza libri" - Thomas Jefferson
TEXT.Spanish: "No puedo vivir sin libros." - Thomas Jefferson

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Paper[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to trade world maps with other civilizations and construct the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]University of Sankore[COLOR_REVERT] wonder.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]papier[COLOR_REVERT] permet d'échanger des cartes du monde avec d'autres civilisations, et de construire l'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Université de Sankoré[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.German: erlaubt den [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Kartenhandel[COLOR_REVERT] zwischen Nationen, ermöglicht das Weltwunder [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Sankoré-Universität[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.Italian: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Carta[COLOR_REVERT] permette lo scambio di mappe mondiali con altre civiltà e la costruzione della Meraviglia [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Università di Sankore[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.Spanish: El [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Papel[COLOR_REVERT] permite intercambiar mapamundis con otras civilizaciones y construir la maravilla de la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Universidad de Sankore[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Parameter Tuning
TEXT.French: Tuning des Paramètres

TEXT.English: Parameter Tuning is the process of designing a universe with basic parameters set at the right values to create novel forms of existence.

"The intelligent beings in these regions should therefore not be surprised if they observe that their locality in the universe satisfies the conditions that are necessary for their existence. It is a bit like a rich person living in a wealthy neighborhood not seeing any poverty."[NEWLINE][SPACE] -Stephen Hawking
TEXT.French: "Les êtres intelligents de ces régions ne devraient donc pas s'étonner s'ils constatent que leur localisation dans l'univers remplit les conditions nécessaires à leur existence. C'est un peu comme une personne riche vivant dans un quartier riche ne voyant aucune pauvreté."[NEWLINE][SPACE] -Stephen Hawking

TEXT.English: TBD
Paraterraforming
TEXT.French: Paraterraformation

TEXT.English: For concepts of how to paraterraform an asteroid, see http://terraforming.wikia.com/wiki/Rocky_Asteroid_Paraterraforming

"...the old Lakota was wise. He knew that a man's heart, away from nature, becomes hard; he knew that lack of respect for growing, living things soon led to lack of respect for humans, too. So he kept his children close to nature's softening influence."[NEWLINE][SPACE] -Standing Bear
TEXT.French: "... le vieux Lakota était sage. Il savait que le cœur d'un homme, loin de la nature, devient dur; il savait que le manque de respect pour les êtres vivants en croissance conduisait bientôt aussi au manque de respect pour les humains. Il a donc gardé ses enfants proches de l'influence adoucissante de la nature."[NEWLINE][SPACE] -Standing Bear

TEXT.English: TBD
Parliaments
TEXT.French: Parlement
TEXT.Polish: Parlament

TEXT.English: A parliament is a legislature whose power and function are similar to those dictated by the Westminster system of the United Kingdom. More generally, "parliament" may simply refer to a democratic government's legislature. The term is derived from the French parlement, the action of parler (to speak): a parlement is a discussion. The term came to mean a meeting at which such a discussion took place. It acquired its modern meaning as it came to be used for the body of people (in an institutional sense) who would meet to discuss matters of state.
TEXT.Polish: Parlament - w państwach o demokratycznych systemach władzy, najwyższy organ przedstawicielski, a jednocześnie zasadniczy organ władzy ustawodawczej. Parlament - w myśl monteskiuszowskiej teorii podziału władzy - jest jednym z trzech pionów władzy państwowej i w żaden sposób nie jest ważniejszy od dwóch pozostałych. W systemach parlamentarno-gabinetowych (np. Polska) parlament jest najwyższym organem władzy państwowej. Z kolei w państwach realnego socjalizmu, parlamenty w mniejszym lub większym zakresie były kontrolowane przez partie komunistyczne.

TEXT.English: "A Parliament is nothing less than a big meeting of more or less idle people." - Walter Bagehot
TEXT.French: "Un Parlement n'est rien de moins qu'une grande réunion de personnes plus ou moins en veille." - Walter Bagehot
TEXT.Spanish: "Un parlamento no es más que una gran reunión de gente más o menos holgazana." - Walter Bagehot
TEXT.Polish: "Parlament nie jest niczym więcej niż wielkim zgromadzeniem bardziej lub mniej próżnych ludzi." - Walter Bagehot

TEXT.English: Research Parliaments to boost your stability
TEXT.French: Recherchez [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Parlement[COLOR_REVERT] pour améliorer la stabilité de votre empire
TEXT.Spanish: Investiga el Parlamento para mejorar tu estabilidad.
TEXT.Polish: Wynajdź Parlamenty by zwiększyć stabilność Twojego Imperium

TEXT.English: Particle Genetics
TEXT.French: Génétique des Particules

TEXT.English: Particle Genetics is the design of life made of AB Matter. The basic unit of life is molecules composed of subatomic particles instead of individual atoms. This allows life to develop highly novel characteristics.
"I have all these great genes, but they're recessive. That's the problem here."[NEWLINE][SPACE] -Bill Watterson
TEXT.French: "J'ai tous ces grands gènes, mais ils sont récessifs. Voilà le problème ici."[NEWLINE][SPACE] -Bill Watterson

TEXT.English: TBD
Patent Rights
TEXT.French: Droits et Brevets
TEXT.Polish: Prawo Patentowe

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Patent Rights[\BOLD], is a form of intellectual property. It consists of a set of exclusive rights granted by a sovereign state to an inventor or their assignee for a limited period of time in exchange for the public disclosure of an invention. The procedure for granting patents, the requirements placed on the patentee, and the extent of the exclusive rights vary widely between countries according to national laws and international agreements. Typically, however, a patent application must include one or more claims defining the invention which must meet the relevant patentability requirements such as novelty and non-obviousness. The exclusive right granted to a patentee in most countries is the right to prevent others from making, using, selling, or distributing the patented invention without permission.
"This is the patent age of new inventions/ For killing bodies, and saving souls,/ All propagated with the best of intentions." - George Gordon
TEXT.French: "Nous sommes dans l'age des brevets des nouvelles inventions / for tuer des corps, sauver des âmes, Tout cela propagé avec les meilleures intentions." - George Gordon
TEXT.Polish: "Jeżeli zgłosisz jakiś patent zawsze okaże się, że ktoś już złożył podobny tydzień temu." - Prawa Klipsteina

TEXT.English: TBD
Patriarchy
TEXT.French: Patriarcat
TEXT.Polish: Patriarchat

TEXT.English: Patriarchy is a social system in which males are the primary authority figures central to social organization, occupying roles of political leadership, moral authority, and control of property, and where fathers hold authority over women and children. It implies the institutions of male rule and privilege, and entails female subordination. Many patriarchal societies are also patrilineal, meaning that property and title are inherited by the male lineage. The female equivalent is matriarchy. Historically, patriarchy has manifested itself in the social, legal, political, and economic organization of a range of different cultures.[PARAGRAPH:2]Anthropological evidence suggests that most prehistoric hunter-gatherer societies were relatively egalitarian, and that patriarchal social structures did not develop until many years after the end of the Pleistocene era, following social and technological innovations such as agriculture and domestication. According to Robert M. Strozier, historical research has not yet found a specific "initiating event". Some scholars point to about six thousand years ago (4000 BCE), when the concept of fatherhood took root, as the beginning of the spread of patriarchy. Domination by men of women is found in the Ancient Near East as far back as 3100 BCE, as are restrictions on a woman's reproductive capacity and exclusion from "the process of representing or the construction of history". With the appearance of the Hebrews, there is also "the exclusion of woman from the God-humanity covenant".
TEXT.French: un Patriarcat is a social system in which males are the primary authority figures central to social organization, occupying roles of political leadership, moral authority, and control of property, and where fathers hold authority over women and children. It implies the institutions of male rule and privilege, and entails female subordination. Many patriarchal societies are also patrilineal, meaning that property and title are inherited by the male lineage. The female equivalent is matriarchy. Historically, patriarchy has manifested itself in the social, legal, political, and economic organization of a range of different cultures.[PARAGRAPH:2]Anthropological evidence suggests that most prehistoric hunter-gatherer societies were relatively egalitarian, and that patriarchal social structures did not develop until many years after the end of the Pleistocene era, following social and technological innovations such as agriculture and domestication. According to Robert M. Strozier, historical research has not yet found a specific "initiating event". Some scholars point to about six thousand years ago (4000 BCE), when the concept of fatherhood took root, as the beginning of the spread of patriarchy. Domination by men of women is found in the Ancient Near East as far back as 3100 BCE, as are restrictions on a woman's reproductive capacity and exclusion from "the process of representing or thela construction de history". With the appearance of the Hebrews, there is also "the exclusion of woman from the God-humanity covenant".
TEXT.Polish: Patriarchat - 1. (z łac.) pater, patris - ojciec, oraz greckiego arche, czyli władza. Jest to typ rodowej organizacji społecznej bazującej na dominującej roli mężczyzn, podkreślanej i wyrażającej się w patrylokalnym małżeństwie i patrylinearnych grupach krewniaczo-pochodzeniowych, w których dziedziczenie następuje po linii męskiej. 2. Ostatni okres ustroju wspólnoty pierwotnej, w którym dominujące stanowisko zajmuje mężczyzna stojący na czele rodu. U starożytnych Latynów nazwa systemu funkcjonowania rodziny, w której ojciec jest głową oraz właścicielem rodziny, ma prawo decydować o życiu i śmierci pozostałych członków rodziny. Taki model rodziny i społeczeństwa (społeczeństwo patriarchalne) obowiązywał w starożytnym Rzymie w okresie królestwa i wczesnej republiki. W późniejszym okresie patriarchat jako model funkcjonowania rodziny występował w wielu społeczeństwach Europy i świata.

TEXT.English: "Maybe the best proof that the language is patriarchal is that it oversimplifies feeling." - Jeffrey Eugenides
TEXT.French: "Peut-être que la meilleure preuve que le language est patriarcal, c'est qu'il simplifie les sentiments." - Jeffrey Eugenides
TEXT.Polish: "Może najlepszym dowodem na to, że język jest tworem patriarchalnym jest zbytnie uproszczenie uczuć." - Jeffrey Eugenides

TEXT.English: TBD
Paved Roads
TEXT.French: Routes Pavées
TEXT.Polish: Drogi Brukowane

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Paved Roads[\BOLD], The world's oldest known paved road was laid in Egypt some time between 2600 and 2200 BC.
TEXT.Polish: Pierwsze drogi powstawały już w IV w. p.n.e. Prowadziły one do sąsiednich miast w Lacjum i Etrurii. Były to między innymi prowadząca do Ostii - Via Ostiensis, prowadząca do Laurentum - Via Laurentina i Via Ardeatina, którą można było dotrzeć do Ardei. Nie były one jednak jeszcze właściwymi drogami rzymskimi. Ich nawierzchnię tworzyła ubita ziemia, a same drogi dopasowywały się do ukształtowania terenu. Pierwszą prawdziwie rzymską drogą była rozpoczęta w 312 p.n.e. przez cenzora Appiusza Klaudiusza Caecusa, Via Appia, łącząca Rzym z Kapuą. Drogę wytyczono w taki sposób, by skrócić odległość do minimum, tak więc całymi kilometrami biegnie ona w linii prostej, a nad doliną Arriccia przez potężny wiadukt. W kolejnych stuleciach chęć uzyskania jak najkrótszej odległości była cechą charakterystyczną rzymskiego budownictwa drogowego. Zmuszała ona budowniczych do budowania licznych mostów (np. granitowy most na Tagu w Alcantara, w Hiszpanii, czy most na Dunaju o długości 1127 metrów niedaleko Drobety w Rumunii), wiaduktów, nasypów, przekopów i tuneli. Innym precedensem jaki wprowadziła Via Appia było nazywanie drogi od nazwiska urzędnika, który nakazał jej budowę (zwyczaj ten stał się powszechny około sto lat po rozpoczęciu budowy drogi do Kapui).

TEXT.English: "The reason the Romans built their great paved highways was because they had such inconvenient footwear." - Charles de Montesquieu
TEXT.French: "La raison pour laquelle les Romains ont construit leurs grandes routes pavées? Parce qu'ils avaient des chaussures très inconfortables." - Charles de Montesquieu
TEXT.Polish: "Powodem dlaczego Rzymianie zbudowali swoją wielką sieć dróg jest ich niewygodne obuwie." - Charles de Montesquieu

TEXT.English: New Route: Paved Roads
TEXT.French: Nouvelle Route: Routes pavées
TEXT.Italian: Permette la costruzione del miglioramento Strada pavimentata.

TEXT.English: Persistence Hunting
TEXT.French: Chasse Persistante
TEXT.Polish: Polowanie Uporczywe

TEXT.English: Persistence hunting (sometimes called endurance hunting) is a hunting technique in which hunters, who may be slower than their prey over short distances, use a combination of running, walking, and tracking to pursue prey until it is exhausted. A persistence hunter must be able to run a long distance over an extended period of time. The strategy is used by a variety of canids such as African wild dogs, and by human hunter-gatherers.[PARAGRAPH:2]Humans are the only surviving primate species that practises persistence hunting. In addition to a capacity for endurance running, human hunters have comparatively little hair, which makes sweating an effective means of cooling the body. Meanwhile, ungulates and other mammals may need to pant to cool down enough, which also means that they must slow down if not remain still.[PARAGRAPH:2]It is still used effectively by the San people in the Kalahari Desert, and by the Rarámuri people of Northwestern Mexico.
TEXT.French: [BOLD]Persistence une Chasse[\BOLD]is a hunting technique in which hunters use a combination of running and tracking to pursue prey to the point of exhaustion. Among primates, endurance running is only seen in humans, and persistence hunting is thought to have been one of the earliest forms of human hunting, having evolved 2 million years ago.
TEXT.Polish: [BOLD]Polowanie Uporczywe[\BOLD] rodzaj polowania wśród ludów pierwotnych, polegający na wielogodzinnym naprzemiennym gonieniu i tropieniu zwierzęcia (również różnych gatunków antylopy, gazeli itp), aż do jego zupełnego wyczerpania. Polowanie odbywa się w często w temperaturze 400C. Człowiek dzięki swojej wytrzymałości kompensuje brak szybkości. Prawdopodobnie miał on również pewien wpływ na ewolucję człowieka. Przypuszcza się, że jest to jeden z najstarszych sposobów polowania stosowany przez ludzi, poprzedzający wynalezienie miotanej broni myśliwskiej. Obecnie tego typu metoda jest stosowana przez niektóre ludy zbieracko-łowieckie, jak Buszmeni na pustyni Kalahari oraz Indianie Tarahumara w Meksyku.

TEXT.English: The secret to a successful hunt is this: Make sure your prey gives up before you do.[PARAGRAPH:2]- Yudishtira,[PARAGRAPH:1][SPACE][SPACE]"CivFanatics Forum: Caveman 2 Cosmos, Audio Quotes, post #324"
TEXT.French: "Voici le secret pour chasser avec succès: Soyez toujours sur que votre proie abandonnera avant vous." - Yudishtira
TEXT.Polish: "Sekret skutecznego polowania to: upewnij się że zwierzyna podda się szybciej niż ty." - Yudishtira

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Persistence Hunting[COLOR_REVERT] is a prehistoric era technology that allows the construction of the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Chaser[COLOR_REVERT] unit and, by using subdued animals, the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Master Hunter[COLOR_REVERT] building that awards [COLOR_GREEN]Experience[COLOR_REVERT] to [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Hunter[COLOR_REVERT] units.
TEXT.French: Une technique de chasse dans laquelle les chasseurs utilisent une à la fois la course et l'endurance pour poursuivre leur proie jusqu'à l'épuisement.
TEXT.Spanish: El ascenso [COLOR_CYAN]Cazador I[COLOR_REVERT] es una buena oportunidad para obtener ventaja sobre los animales salvajes.
TEXT.Polish: Odblokowuje [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Szałas Łowcy[COLOR_REVERT] i [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Chatę Myśliwych[COLOR_REVERT]. Udostępnia promocje: Łowca I i Uderz i Uciekaj.

TEXT.English: Personalized Health
TEXT.French: Guérison par le Génome
TEXT.German: Individuelle Medizin
TEXT.Polish: Spersonalizowana Opieka Medyczna

TEXT.English: Advances in medical genetics and human genetics have enabled a more detailed understanding of the impact of genetics and mutations that cause illness and disease. Machine Learning and Augmented Reality imaging of the human body in the operating table on have made it possible to create new diagnostic tools that diagnose, treat, and prevent new illnesses, down to the atomic level.[PARAGRAPH:2]Personalized medicine is a medical model that proposes the customization of healthcare, with all decisions and practices being tailored to the individual patient by use of genetic or other information.[PARAGRAPH:2]Traditional clinical diagnosis and management focuses on the individual patient's clinical signs and symptoms, medical and family history, and data from laboratory and imaging evaluation to diagnose and treat illnesses are now considered obsolete.[PARAGRAPH:2]The field of proteomics, or the comprehensive analysis and characterization of all the proteins and protein isoforms encoded by the human genome, has a great impact on personalized medicine. This is because while the DNA genome is the information archive, it is the proteins that do the work of the cell: the functional aspects of the cell are controlled by and through proteins, not genes.[PARAGRAPH:2]With protemics, the days of sitting in a doctor's office are of the ancient past, a blood or tissue sample is analyzed and a readout of virtually all of your biological functions are analyzed to give you a personalized treatment or prevention plan. Diagnosis is also accerelated because most of the known diseases are categorized and your sample is matched to determine a diagnosis.
"To keep the body in good health is a duty, otherwise we shall not be able to keep our mind strong and clear." - Buddha
TEXT.French: "Garder le corps en bonne santé est un devoir, sinon nous ne pourrons pas garder notre esprit fort et clair." - Buddha
TEXT.Polish: "Jest obowiązkiem utrzymywać swoje ciało w dobrym zdrowiu, inaczej nie jesteśmy w stanie utrzymać silnego i jasnego umysłu." - Budda

TEXT.English: TBD
Personal Adornments
TEXT.French: Parures et Ornements
TEXT.Polish: Zdobienie Ciał

TEXT.English: An adornment is generally an accessory or ornament worn to enhance the beauty or status of the wearer. They are often worn to embellish, enhance, or distinguish the wearer, and to define cultural, social, or religious status within a specific community. When worn to show economic status, the items are often either rare or prohibitively expensive to others. Adornments are usually colourful, and worn to attract attention.[PARAGRAPH:2]They have a long history, around the world, from feathers or bone, to modern accessories, such as jewellery. Items of adornment are also used by warriors, and by other members of the military to show rank or achievement. These include cosmetics, jewellery, clothing accessories, facial hair, fingernail modification, piercing, lip plates, tattooing, braiding, and headgear.[PARAGRAPH:2]Groups who practice adornment include the Yakuza, military, religious institutions, tribal groups, and the punk culture. Items of adornment can tell us about a person's rank, social status, gender role, area of origin, etc. An example would be the beaded jewelry worn by the Maasai tribe, which is very specific to them and some related tribes.
TEXT.French: [BOLD]Parures et Ornements[\BOLD], Different cultural groups have evolved different ways of decorating themselves avec shells and one can often guess which tribe a person comes from by the shells being worn.
TEXT.Polish: [BOLD]Zdobienie Ciał[\BOLD], Różne grupy kulturowe wykształciły różne sposoby ozdabiania się za pomocą muszelek. Pozwalało to na łatwe rozróżnienie pochodzenia i przynależności do poszczególnych grup i plemion.

TEXT.English: Humanity can be roughly divided into three sorts of people - those who find comfort in literature, those who find comfort in personal adornment, and those who find comfort in food.[PARAGRAPH:2]- Elizabeth Goudge,[PARAGRAPH:1][SPACE][SPACE]"The Little White Horse"
TEXT.French: "L'humanité peut être divisée en trois sortes de gens - ceux qui trouvent du réconfort dans la littérature, ceux qui trouvent du réconfort dans la parure, et ceux qui trouvent du réconfort dans la nourriture." - Elizabeth Goudge
TEXT.Polish: "Nie można logicznie udowodnić, że coś jest piękne, trzeba to po prostu odczuć." - Antoni Kępiński

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Personal Adornments[COLOR_REVERT] is a prehistoric era technology that unlocks a number of [ICON_GOLD][COLOR_GREEN]Gold[COLOR_REVERT] producing buildings, including the powerful [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Jewelry Store[COLOR_REVERT] which increases a city's overall [ICON_GOLD][COLOR_GREEN]Gold[COLOR_REVERT] output.
TEXT.French: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Parures et Ornements[COLOR_REVERT] est une technologie de l'ère préhistorique qui permet la construction de bâtiments générant de l'[ICON_GOLD][COLOR_GREEN]Or[COLOR_REVERT], comme la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Bijouterie[COLOR_REVERT] qui augmente le rendement global de l'[ICON_GOLD][COLOR_GREEN]Or[COLOR_REVERT] de la Ville.
TEXT.Polish: Udostępnia: Kapelusze i Biżuterię. Odblokowuje [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Chatkę Wytwórcy Masek[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Sklep z Kapeluszami[COLOR_REVERT] i [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Jubilera[COLOR_REVERT]. Pozwala wyszkolić [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Łotrzyka[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Personal Computers
TEXT.Polish: Komputery Osobiste

TEXT.English: A personal computer (PC) is a general-purpose computer, whose size, capabilities and original sale price makes it useful for individuals, and is intended to be operated directly by an end-user with no intervening computer operator. This contrasted with the batch processing or time-sharing models which allowed larger, more expensive minicomputer and mainframe systems to be used by many people, usually at the same time. Large data processing systems require a full-time staff to operate efficiently.[PARAGRAPH:2]Software applications for most personal computers include, but are not limited to, word processing, spreadsheets, databases, Web browsers and e-mail clients, digital media playback, games and myriad personal productivity and special-purpose software applications. Modern personal computers often have connections to the Internet, allowing access to the World Wide Web and a wide range of other resources. Personal computers may be connected to a local area network (LAN), either by a cable or a wireless connection. A personal computer may be a desktop computer or a laptop, Netbook, tablet or a handheld PC (Palmtop).
TEXT.Polish: Komputer osobisty (ang. personal computer) - mikrokomputer przeznaczony przede wszystkim do użytku osobistego w domu i biurze. Służy głównie do uruchamiania oprogramowania biurowego, dostępu do zasobów Internetu, prezentacji treści multimedialnych (tekst, obrazy, dźwięki, filmy i inne), jak i gier. Wraz ze wzrostem mocy obliczeniowych komputerów osobistych stało się możliwe wykorzystanie ich w roli stacji roboczych i małych serwerów. Niska cena, jak i dostępność oprogramowania na licencjach FLOSS zachęciła niektórych do budowania na ich podstawie klastrów komputerowych. Dość popularne stały się też rozproszone obliczenia (na przykład w projektach typu SETI@home) oraz grid.

TEXT.English: "People think computers will keep them from making mistakes. They're wrong. With computers you make mistakes faster." - Adam Osborne
TEXT.French: "Les gens pensent que les ordinateurs les empêcheront de faire des erreurs. Ils ont tort. Avec les ordinateurs, vous faites des erreurs plus rapidement." - Adam Osborne
TEXT.Polish: "Ludzie myślą, że komputery ustrzegą ich od błędów. Błąd. Będą poprostu popełniać błędy szybciej." - Adam Osborne

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Personal Computers[COLOR_REVERT] enables the construction of the [COLOR_PROJECT_TEXT]Internet[COLOR_REVERT] project. It also obsoletes [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Angkor Wat[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]The University of Sankore[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]The Spiral Minaret[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]informatique[COLOR_REVERT] permet la création d'[COLOR_PROJECT_TEXT]Internet[COLOR_REVERT] et la construction des puissants [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Blindés modernes[COLOR_REVERT]. Elle entraîne aussi l'obsolescence de l'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Angkor Vat[COLOR_REVERT], de l'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Université de Sankore[COLOR_REVERT] et du [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Minaret en Spirale[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.German: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Computertechnologie[COLOR_REVERT] ermöglicht den Bau des [COLOR_PROJECT_TEXT]Internet[COLOR_REVERT]-Projekts und der mächtigen [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Kampfpanzerung[COLOR_REVERT]. Sie macht außerdem [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Angkor Wat[COLOR_REVERT], die [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Universität von Sankore[COLOR_REVERT] und das [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Spiralminarett[COLOR_REVERT] überflüssig.
TEXT.Italian: I [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Computer[COLOR_REVERT] permettono la costruzione del progetto [COLOR_PROJECT_TEXT]Internet[COLOR_REVERT] e delle potenti [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Unità corazzate[COLOR_REVERT]. Inoltre rendono obsolete le Meraviglie [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Angkor Wat[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Università di Sankore[COLOR_REVERT] e [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Minareto a spirale[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.Spanish: Los [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Ordenadores[COLOR_REVERT] permiten la construcción del proyecto [COLOR_PROJECT_TEXT]Internet[COLOR_REVERT] y del potente [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Blindado moderno[COLOR_REVERT]. También dejan obsoletos [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Angkor Wat[COLOR_REVERT], la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Universidad de Sankore[COLOR_REVERT] y el [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Minarete Helicoidal[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Personal Robots
TEXT.French: Robots Personnels
TEXT.German: Persönliche Roboter
TEXT.Polish: Osobiste Roboty

TEXT.English: A personal robot is one whose human interface and design make it useful for individuals. This is by contrast to industrial robots which are generally configured and operated by robotics specialists. A personal robot is one that enables an individual to automate the repetitive or menial part of home or work life making them more productive.[PARAGRAPH:2]Similar to the way that the transition from mainframe computers to the personal computers revolutionized personal productivity, the transition from industrial robotics to personal robotics is changing productivity in home and work settings. [PARAGRAPH:3]Turning a robot like ASIMO or into a universally applicable personal robot or artificial servant is mainly a programming task. As of 2011 vast improvements in motion planning, computer vision (esp. scene recognition), natural language processing, and automated reasoning are indispensable to make this a possibility.
TEXT.Polish: Najbardziej znanymi robotami rozrywkowymi są: interaktywny pluszowy Furby'ie, humanoidalny Robosapien oraz przypominający szczeniaka, wyposażony w zmysły wzroku, słuchu, dotyku i równowagi Aibo. Organizowane są liczne konkursy w których rywalizują ze sobą roboty, gdzie zadania rozpościerają się od eksploracji labiryntu, przez walkę z innymi robotami (BattleBots), aż do gry w piłkę nożną (RoboCup). W Polsce organizowany jest konkurs robotów tańczących - RoboDance, a także znekBOT - konkurs na roboty autonomiczne z misją kosmiczną w tle. W sztuce roboty są używane w tworzeniu instalacji, również np. przy wspólnych występach z ludźmi.

TEXT.English: "Let's start with the three fundamental Rules of Robotics... We have: one, a robot may not injure a human being, or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm. Two, a robot must obey the orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the First Law. And three, a robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the First or Second Laws." - Isaac Asimov
TEXT.French: "Commençons par les trois règles fondamentales de la robotique... Nous avons: Un, un robot ne peut blesser un ètre humain ou, par son inaction, permettre qu'un ètre humain soit exposé au danger. Deux, un robot doit obéir aux ordres donnés par les ètres humains, sauf si de tels ordres sont en contradiction avec la Première Loi. Et trois, un robot doit protéger sa propre existence tant que cette protection n'entre pas en conflit avec la Première ou la Seconde loi." - Isaac Asimov
TEXT.Polish: "Robot nie może skrzywdzić istoty ludzkiej lub pozwolić, by stała się jej krzywda. Robot musi wypełniać rozkazy istoty ludzkiej, o ile nie pogwałci tym samym Pierwszego Prawa. Robot musi chronić sam siebie, o ile nie pogwałci tym samym Pierwszego lub Drugiego Prawa." - Isaac Asimov

TEXT.English: TBD
Perspective
TEXT.German: Perspektive
TEXT.Polish: Perspektywa

TEXT.English: Perspective (from Latin perspicere, to see through) in the graphic arts, such as drawing, is an approximate representation, on a flat surface (such as paper), of an image as it is perceived by the eye.[PARAGRAPH:2]Before perspective, paintings and drawings typically sized objects and characters according to their spiritual or thematic importance, not with distance. Especially in Medieval art, art was meant to be read as a group of symbols, rather than seen as a coherent picture. The only method to show distance was by overlapping characters. Overlapping alone made poor drawings of architecture; medieval paintings of cities are a hodgepodge of lines in every direction. With the exception of dice, heraldry typically ignores perspective in the treatment of charges, though sometimes in later centuries charges are specified as in perspective.[PARAGRAPH:2]Perspective perhaps first entered mainstream artistic use around the 5th century B.C. in ancient Greece in the subject of skenographia: using a flat panel on a stage to give the illusion of depth. The philosophers Anaxagoras and Democritus worked out geometric theories of perspective for use with skenographia. Alcibiades had paintings in his house designed based on skenographia, thus this art was not confined merely to the stage. Euclid's Optics introduced a mathematical theory of perspective; however, there is some debate over the extent to which Euclid's perspective coincides with a modern mathematical definition of perspective.[PARAGRAPH:2]A clearly modern optical basis of perspective was given in 1021, when Alhazen, an Iraqi physicist and mathematician, in his Book of Optics, explained that light projects conically into the eye. This was, theoretically, enough to translate objects convincingly onto a painting, but Alhalzen was concerned only with optics, not with painting. Conical translations are mathematically difficult, so a drawing constructed using them would be incredibly time-consuming.[PARAGRAPH:2]In about 1415, Filippo Brunelleschi demonstrated the geometrical method of perspective, used today by artists, by painting the outlines of various Florentine buildings onto a mirror. When the building's outline was continued, he noticed that all the lines converged on the horizon line. According to Vasari, he then set up a demonstration of his painting of the Baptistry in the incomplete doorway of the Duomo. He had the viewer look through a small hole on the back of the painting, facing the Baptistry. He would then set up a mirror, facing the viewer, which reflected his painting. To the viewer, the painting of the Baptistry and the Baptistry itself were nearly indistinguishable.[PARAGRAPH:2]Soon after, nearly every artist in Florence used geometrical perspective in their paintings, notably Donatello, who started sculpting elaborate checkerboard floors into the simple manger portrayed in the birth of Christ. Although hardly historically accurate, these checkerboard floors obeyed the primary laws of geometrical perspective: all lines converged to a vanishing point, and the rate at which the horizontal lines receded into the distance was graphically determined. This became an integral part of Quattrocento art. Not only was perspective a way of showing depth, it was also a new method of composing a painting. Paintings began to show a single, unified scene, rather than a combination of several.
TEXT.Polish: Perspektywa określenie stosowane w architekturze, malarstwie, fotografii i innych sztukach wizualnych oznaczające sposób oddania trójwymiarowych obiektów i przestrzeni na płaszczyźnie. Istnieje kilka rodzajów perspektywy: linearna (zbieżna, geometryczna), barwna (malarska), powietrzna, odwrócona.

TEXT.English: "Only the artist, not the fool, discovers that which nature hides." - Filippo Brunelleschi
TEXT.French: "Seul l'artiste, pas le fou, découvre ce que cache la nature." - Filippo Brunelleschi
TEXT.Polish: "Tylko artysta, nie głupiec, odkrywa to co natura ukrywa." - Filippo Brunelleschi

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Perspective[COLOR_REVERT] enables the construction of [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]The Sistine Chapel[COLOR_REVERT] and leads to more advanced art forms.
TEXT.French: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Perspective[COLOR_REVERT] rend actif thela construction de des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]La Chapelle Sixtine[COLOR_REVERT] and mène vers more advanced art forms.
TEXT.Spanish: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Perspectiva[COLOR_REVERT] permite la construcción de la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Capilla Sixtina[COLOR_REVERT] y lleva a expresiones artísticas más avanzadas.

TEXT.English: Petroglyphs
TEXT.French: Pétroglyphes
TEXT.German: Felszeichnungen
TEXT.Polish: Petroglify

TEXT.English: Petroglyphs are images created by removing part of a rock surface by incising, picking, carving, or abrading, as a form of rock art. Outside North America, scholars often use terms such as "carving", "engraving", or other descriptions of the technique to refer to such images. Petroglyphs are found worldwide, and are often associated with prehistoric peoples.[PARAGRAPH:2]The term petroglyph should not be confused with petrograph, which is an image drawn or painted on a rock face. Both types of image belong to the wider and more general category of rock art or parietal art. Petroforms, or patterns and shapes made by many large rocks and boulders over the ground, are also quite different. Inuksuit are also unique, and found only in the Arctic (except for reproductions and imitations built in more southerly latitudes).[PARAGRAPH:2]Another form of petroglyph, normally found in literate cultures, a rock relief or rock-cut relief is a relief sculpture carved on "living rock" such as a cliff, rather than a detached piece of stone. While these relief carvings are a category of rock art, sometimes found in conjunction with rock-cut architecture, they tend to be omitted in most works on rock art, which concentrate on engravings and paintings by prehistoric or nonliterate cultures. Some of these reliefs exploit the rock's natural properties to define an image. Rock reliefs have been made in many cultures, especially in the Ancient Near East. Rock reliefs are generally fairly large, as they need to be to make an impact in the open air. Most have figures that are larger than life-size.[PARAGRAPH:2]Some petroglyphs might be as old as 40,000 years, and petroglyph sites in Australia are estimated to date back 27,000 years. Many petroglyphs are dated to approximately the Neolithic and late Upper Paleolithic boundary, about 10,000 to 12,000 years ago, if not earlier, such as Kamyana Mohyla. Around 7,000 to 9,000 years ago, other precursors of writing systems, such as pictographs and ideograms, began to appear. Petroglyphs were still common though, and some cultures continued using them much longer, even until contact with Western culture was made in the 19th and 20th centuries. Petroglyphs have been found in all parts of the globe except Antarctica, with the highest concentrations in parts of Africa, Scandinavia, Siberia, southwestern North America, and Australia.
TEXT.Polish: [BOLD]Petroglify[\BOLD] wyryte w skale rysunki, na ogół prehistoryczne dzieła ludzi z ery neolitycznej. Są one ważną formą przedliterackich symboli, używanych od około 10. tysiąclecia p.n.e. do czasów współczesnych, mających różnorodne formy zależnie od czasu i miejsca powstania.

TEXT.English: The venerable woods - rivers that move in majesty, and the complaining brooks that make the meadows green, and, poured round all, Old Ocean's gray and melancholy waste, are but the solemn decorations all of the great tomb of man.[PARAGRAPH:2]- William Cullen Bryant,[PARAGRAPH:1][SPACE][SPACE]"Thanatopsis"
TEXT.French: "Les bois vénérables; Des Rivières qui se déplacent[NEWLINE]En majesté, et les plaignants ruisseaux[NEWLINE]qui rendent les prairies vertes; et ces pauvres alentours,[NEWLINE]Ce Vieux Gris océan et cet ennui mélancolique,[NEWLINE]sont toutes les décorations solennelles[NEWLINE]du majestueux tombeau de l'Homme." - William Cullen Bryant, Thanatopsis
TEXT.Polish: "Malowidła nie powinny być zbyt malownicze." - Ralph Waldo Emerson

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Petroglyphs[COLOR_REVERT] is a prehistoric era technology that unlocks the construction of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Lascaux Paints[COLOR_REVERT] world wonder.
TEXT.French: Bonus culturel disponible, sous la forme de Peintures rupestres.
TEXT.Spanish: Las Pinturas rupestres aportarán un notable impulso a la cultura al principio de la partida.
TEXT.Polish: Odblokowuje budynki zwiększające kulturę.

TEXT.English: Phasing
TEXT.French: Déphasage
TEXT.Polish: Fazowanie

TEXT.English: Phasing is an extended ability to hold a state of transtangibility, bursts of which are enabled at Transtangible Neutrino Accelerators. It's an immaterial state but it is not bi-locational in time or space, which is what you get with Transverse Euclidean Geometry. It happens to also be a new form of invisibility. Few weapons can affect a phased object - even fewer still can affect a 4D object. 2 distinct stages of development and 2 distinct 'states'.[PARAGRAPH:2]A unit can be BOTH Phased and 4 Dimensional (which would offer a great deal of protection and utility and it's an ability that is never earned by 'Naval' Vessels as by this point the whole purpose in differentiating between Naval and Space vehicles has become as obsolete as most land vehicles have become by the last stage of this Naval Upgrade chain.)
TEXT.Polish: Fazowanie (załamywanie krawędzi) - wykonywanie faz poprzez usunięcie materiału na krawędzi detalu (przedmiotu), najczęściej poprzez obróbkę skrawaniem za pomocą wierteł, noży tokarskich, pilników oraz specjalnych urządzeń elektryczno-gazowych. Wymiar fazy określa się przez podanie kąta i długości, na której ma być wykonana faza, np. 1x45o. Najczęściej fazuje się wałki i otwory, ułatwia to późniejszy montaż oraz poprawia estetykę.

TEXT.English: "Material things I know, or fell, or see; All else is immaterial to me." - Jamrach Holobom
TEXT.French: "Les choses matérielles que je connais, que je suis tombé ou que je vois; Tout le reste ne m'importe pas." - Jamrach Holobom
TEXT.Polish: "Wszystko co materialne jest dla mnie widzialne, znane lub mogę to wyczuć. Reszta jest dla mnie niematerialna." - Jamrach Holobom

TEXT.English: Phasing is, in game terms, effectively a new defense and form of enhanced stealth.
TEXT.French: Le phasage est, dans le jeu, effectivement une nouvelle défense et une forme de furtivité améliorée.

TEXT.English: Philosophy
TEXT.Polish: Filozofia

TEXT.English: The word "philosophy" comes from a Greek term meaning "love of wisdom." In ancient Greece, literacy and an interest in the natural world were common in a burgeoning upper class. In their leisure time, these people contemplated principles of thinking and being, logic and mathematics, and the natures of reality and existence. In ancient times, the study of philosophy was indistinguishable from the study of science, and many of the theories formulated by the early philosophers became the basis for studies in the fields of astronomy, medicine, chemistry, and physics. The teachings and writings of the ancient philosophers of Greece and the Orient also, in part, laid the groundwork for many of the world's oldest organized religions.
TEXT.French: Le mot "philosophie" vient du Grec et signifie "amour de la sagesse". Dans la Grèce antique, l'alphabétisation et l'intérêt pour le monde étaient fréquents au sein de la haute société naissante. Dans leurs moments de loisir, ces personnes réfléchissaient sur les principes de la pensée et de l'être, sur la logique et les mathématiques mais aussi sur la nature de la réalité et de l'existence. Durant l'Antiquité, l'étude de la philosophie n'était pas différenciée de celle des sciences et de nombreuses théories formulées par les premiers philosophes ont servi de base pour l'étude de l'astronomie, de la médecine, de la chimie et de la physique. Les enseignements et les textes des philosophes grecs et orientaux ont aussi, dans une certaine mesure, préparé le terrain pour la plupart des plus anciennes religions organisées du monde.
TEXT.German: Der Begriff "Philosophie" stammt aus dem Griechischen und bedeutet etwa "Liebe zur Weisheit". Im antiken Griechenland bestand innerhalb der aufkeimenden Oberschicht oftmals ein Interesse an der Literatur und am Verständnis der Natur. In der Freizeit wurden Prinzipien des Denkens und des Daseins, der Logik und der Mathematik, sowie des Wesens der Realität und der Existenz diskutiert. In der Antike waren philosophische und wissenschaftliche Studien ein und dasselbe, und viele durch frühe Philosophen formulierte Theorien wurden zur Basis von astronomischen, medizinischen, chemikalischen und physikalischen Studien. Die Lehren und Schriften antiker griechischer und orientalischer Philosophen legten teilweise die Fundamente für einige der ältesten organisierten Weltreligionen.
TEXT.Italian: Il termine "filosofia" deriva dal Greco e significa "amore per la sapienza". Nell'antica Grecia, l'erudizione e l'interesse per il mondo naturale erano comuni nelle classi superiori; nel tempo libero, i loro membri amavano riflettere e discutere tra loro sull'origine del pensiero e dell'essere, di logica e di matematica e sulla natura della realtà e dell'esistenza. Lo studio della filosofia era allora indistinguibile da quello della scienza e molte delle teorie formulate dai primi filosofi diventarono le basi per gli studi di astronomia, medicina, chimica e fisica. Gli insegnamenti e le opere degli antichi filosofi Greci e Orientali posero le basi ideologiche per lo sviluppo di alcune delle più antiche religioni del mondo.
TEXT.Spanish: El término “filosofía” deriva de un vocablo griego que significa “amor por la sabiduría”. En la antigua Grecia, la educación y el interés por el mundo natural caracterizaban a las clases acomodadas. En su tiempo libre, estas personas meditaban sobre los principios del pensamiento y el ser, la lógica y las matemáticas, la naturaleza de la realidad y la existencia. En la Antigüedad, el estudio de la filosofía era indistinguible del estudio de la ciencia, y muchas de las teorías formuladas por los primeros filósofos se convirtieron en la base para estudios posteriores en los campos de la astronomía, la medicina, la química y la física. Las enseñanzas y escritos de los antiguos filósofos de Grecia y de Oriente establecieron, en parte, la base para muchas de las más antiguas religiones organizadas del mundo.

TEXT.English: "I have gained this by philosophy: that I do without being commanded what others do only from fear of the law." - Aristotle
TEXT.French: "La philosophie m'a appris ceci: ce que je fais sans que l'on me l'ordonne, les autres le font par crainte de la loi." - Aristote
TEXT.German: "Dies habe ich durch Philosophie gewonnen. Dass ich tue, ohne befohlen zu werden, was andere nur aus Furcht vor dem Gesetz tun." - Aristoteles (384-322 v.Chr.)
TEXT.Italian: "Con la filosofia ho conquistato il diritto di fare ciò che voglio senza essere comandato da chi lo fa solo per timore della legge." - Aristotele
TEXT.Spanish: "Con la filosofía he logrado lo siguiente: hacer, sin que me lo ordenen, lo que otros hacen solamente por temor a la ley." - Aristóteles

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Philosophy[COLOR_REVERT] enables the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pacifism[COLOR_REVERT] civic and allows construction of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Angkor Wat[COLOR_REVERT] wonder.
TEXT.French: La[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]philosophie[COLOR_REVERT] permet d'instaurer le [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]pacifisme[COLOR_REVERT] et de construire [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Angkor Vat[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.German: erlaubt die Gesellschaftsform [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pazifismus[COLOR_REVERT], ermöglicht das Weltwunder [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Angkor Wat[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.Italian: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Filosofia[COLOR_REVERT] permette la realizzazione della forma di governo [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pacifismo[COLOR_REVERT] e la costruzione della Meraviglia [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Angkor Wat[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.Spanish: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Filosofía[COLOR_REVERT] activa el principio del [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pacifismo[COLOR_REVERT] y permite la construcción de la maravilla de [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Angkor Wat[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Photography
TEXT.German: Fotografie
TEXT.Polish: Fotografia

TEXT.English: Photography is the process of recording pictures by means of capturing light on a light-sensitive medium, such as a film or electronic sensor. Light patterns reflected or emitted from objects expose a sensitive silver halide based chemical or electronic medium during a timed exposure, usually through a photographic lens in a device known as a camera that also stores the resulting information chemically or electronically.[PARAGRAPH:2]Photography is the result of combining several technical discoveries. Long before the first photographs were made, Ibn al-Haytham (Alhazen) (965 - 1040) invented the camera obscura and pinhole camera, Albertus Magnus (1193 - 1280) discovered silver nitrate, and Georges Fabricius (1516 - 1571) discovered silver chloride. Daniel Barbaro described a diaphragm in 1568. Wilhelm Homberg described how light darkened some chemicals (photochemical effect) in 1694. The fiction book Giphantie (by the French Thiphaigne de La Roche, 1729-1774) described what can be interpreted as photography.[PARAGRAPH:2]Photography as a usable process goes back to the 1820s with the development of chemical photography. The first permanent photograph was an image produced in 1826 by the French inventor Nicephore Niepce.
TEXT.Polish: Fotografia to zbiór wielu różnych technik, których celem jest zarejestrowanie trwałego, pojedynczego obrazu za pomocą światła. Potoczne znaczenie zakłada wykorzystanie układu optycznego, choć nie jest to konieczne - fotografia otworkowa, rayografia. Fotografia, powstała w XIX wieku, korzystała z wynalazków znanych już wcześniej. Podstawowy instrument do tworzenia obrazu, camera obscura, był stosowany już od XVI wieku przez malarzy. W 1826 lub 1827 powstała pierwsza fotografia stworzona przez Francuza Josepha-Nicephore'a Niepce'a na wypolerowanej płycie metalowej. Rok 1839 uznaje się za właściwą datę wynalezienia fotografii. Francuz, Louis Jacques Daguerre, zademonstrował Akademii Francuskiej zdjęcie fotograficzne otrzymane na warstewce jodku srebra, powstałej w wyniku działania pary jodu na wypolerowaną płytę miedzianą pokrytą srebrem. Technika fotografii rozwijała się od tego momentu bardzo szybko. Już wkrótce płytki srebrne lub arkusze papieru zastąpiono płytkami szklanymi powleczonymi warstwą światłoczułą. Płytki te preparowano tuż przed wykonaniem zdjęcia, co wymagało przenośnej ciemni fotograficznej, w której można było dokonać tego zabiegu. W 1861 udało się uzyskać pierwszą trwałą fotografię barwną fizykowi Jamesowi Clerkowi Maxwellowi. W 1907 Bracia Lumiere wprowadzili na rynek pierwsze płyty do fotografii barwnej, Autochrome. Były one wyprodukowane na bazie barwionej skrobi ziemniaczanej. 1935 został wprowadzony do sprzedaży pierwszy współczesny, trójwarstwowy film barwny, Kodachrome. Większość współczesnych filmów barwnych, oprócz Kodachrome, wykorzystuje technologię stworzoną dla filmu Agfacolor w 1936. Od 1963 jest dostępny natychmiastowy materiał kolorowy firmy Polaroid. Fotografia pojawiła się na ziemiach polskich już w roku 1839, kiedy to Kurier Warszawski wydrukował ogłoszenie firmy FRAGET oferującej aparaty do dagerotypii. Rok później w Poznaniu i w Warszawie pojawiły się ilustrowane broszury poświęcone dagerotypii.

TEXT.English: "Not everybody trusts paintings but people believe photographs." - Ansel Adams
TEXT.French: "Tout le monde ne fait pas confiance aux peintures, mais les gens croient les photos." - Ansel Adams
TEXT.Polish: "Nie każdy ufa obrazom, ale ludzie wierzą w fotografie." - Ansel Adams

TEXT.English: Photography allows later the construction of Accelerator and Press Agency city improvements and lead the way to more media solutions.
TEXT.French: La photographie permet plus tard la construction des améliorations de la ville de l'accélérateur et de l'agence de presse et ouvre la voie à davantage de solutions médiatiques.
TEXT.Spanish: La Fotografía permitirá la construcción del Acelerador de partículas y la Agencia de prensa, y abre el camino a otros medios de comunicación.

TEXT.English: Photonic Satellites
TEXT.French: Satellites Photoniques
TEXT.Polish: Satelity Fotonowe

TEXT.English: Photonic Satellites are satellites which purely communicate with lasers. This allows for largely undistorted direct contact with another satellite at high speeds, but with minimal chance of interception.

"As a nation we have, over the past seven years, been rebuilding our intelligence with powerful capabilities that many thought we would no longer need after the Cold War. We have been rebuilding our clandestine service, our satellite and other technical collection, our analytical depth and expertise." - George Tenet
TEXT.French: "En tant que nation, nous avons, au cours des sept dernières années, été reconstruisons notre intelligence avec des capacités puissantes que beaucoup pensaient que nous ne serions plus besoin après la Guerre froide. Nous avons été en train de reconstruire notre service clandestin, notre satellite et autre collection technique, notre profondeur d'analyse et d'expertise." - George Tenet
TEXT.Polish: "Jako naród przez kilka ostatnich lat budujemy nasz wywiadz potężnymi możliwościam, mimo że zimno wojna się skończyła. Z tymi wszystkimi satelitami i całą tą technologicznymi możliwościami, z tymi całym aparatem analitycznym i eksperckim." - George Tenet

TEXT.English: TBD
Photon Thermodynamics
TEXT.French: Thermodynamique Photonique
TEXT.Polish: Termodynamika Fotonów

TEXT.English: In physics, a photon gas is a gas-like collection of photons, which has many of the same properties of a conventional gas like hydrogen or neon - including pressure, temperature, and entropy. Photon Thermodynamics refers to the use of photon gas commercially in civilian and the creation of heat weapons The most common example of a photon gas in equilibrium is black body radiation. A massive ideal gas with only one type of particle is uniquely described by three state functions such as the temperature, volume, and the number of particles. However, for a black body, the energy distribution is established by the interaction of the photons with matter, usually the walls of the container. In this interaction, the number of photons is not conserved. As a result, the chemical potential of the black body photon gas is zero. The number of state functions needed to describe a black body state is thus reduced from three to two (e.g. temperature and volume).[PARAGRAPH:2]A very important difference between a gas of massive particles and a photon gas with a black body distribution is that the number of photons in the system is not conserved. A photon may collide with an electron in the wall, exciting it to a higher energy state, removing a photon from the photon gas. This electron may drop back to its lower level in a series of steps, each one of which releases an individual photon back into the photon gas. Although the sum of the energies of the emitted photons are the same as the absorbed photon, the number of emitted photons will vary. It can be shown that, as a result of this lack of constraint on the number of photons in the system, the chemical potential of the photons must be zero for black body radiation.
"Just as a candle cannot burn without fire, men cannot live without a spiritual life." - Buddha
TEXT.French: "Tout comme une bougie ne peut pas brûler sans feu, les hommes ne peuvent pas vivre sans vie spirituelle." - Buddha
TEXT.Polish: "Tak jak świeca nie może płonąć bez ognia, człowiek nie może przeżyć bez życia duchowego." - Budda

TEXT.English: TBD
Physical Chemistry
TEXT.French: Chimie physique

TEXT.English: Polymerization of monomers to form high-molecular-weight molecules in the presence of catalysts.

"According to the Law of Cause and Effect, every effect must have a cause. In other words, everything that happens has a catalyst; everything that came into being has something that caused it. Things don't just happen by themselves." - Ray Comfort
TEXT.French: "Selon la loi de cause à effet, chaque effet doit avoir une cause. En d'autres termes, tout ce qui se passe a un catalyseur; tout ce qui est né a quelque chose qui l'a causé. Les choses ne se produisent pas seules." - Ray Comfort

TEXT.English: Advancements in material sciences often lead to powerful discoveries and utilizations.
TEXT.French: Les progrès des sciences des matériaux conduisent souvent à de puissantes découvertes et utilisations.

TEXT.English: Physics
TEXT.Polish: Fizyka

TEXT.English: Physics is the study of the many forms of matter and energy and the way they interact with themselves and each other. A number of ancient races made observations about certain aspects of physics, such as planetary motion, but were unable to develop theories as to the reasons for these motions. Some of the earliest applications of physics were by the Greek mathematician Archimedes, who applied physics to create such devices as levers and screws. It was not until the 17th century that experimental methods and scientific measuring devices led to a true understanding of many fundamental physical laws. Early scientists such as Johannes Kepler and Sir Isaac Newton began to disprove the theories of the ancient Greek philosophers and scientifically prove their theories concerning the laws of physics. Discoveries in physics rarely have direct applications, however they do provide a basic understanding of the laws governing the universe, thus forming the basis for practical advances in technology.
TEXT.French: La physique est l'étude des nombreuses formes de la matière, de l'énergie et de leurs interactions. De nombreuses civilisations anciennes ont observé certains aspects de la physique, comme le mouvement des planètes, mais n'ont pas été capables de produire des théories sur les raisons de ce mouvement. Certaines des premières applications de la physique sont le fruit des recherches du mathématicien grec Archimède, qui a mis en pratique ses connaissances pour créer des mécanismes, comme le levier ou la vis. Ce n'est qu'au XVIIe siècle que des méthodes expérimentales et des appareils de mesures scientifiques ont permis d'accéder à une véritable compréhension de nombreuses lois physiques fondamentales. Les premiers scientifiques, tels que Johannes Kepler ou Isaac Newton, ont commencé à réfuter les théories des philosophes grecs de l'Antiquité et à démontrer scientifiquement leurs propres théories concernant les lois de la physique. Les découvertes en physique trouvent rarement des applications directes. Cependant, elles fournissent une compréhension fondamentale des lois gouvernant l'univers et favorisent ainsi les progrès technologiques.
TEXT.German: Die Physik erforscht die Erscheinungsformen der Materie und Energie sowie der untereinander bestehenden Wechselwirkungen. Einige antike Kulturen nahmen hinsichtlich bestimmter Aspekte der Physik gezielte Beobachtungen vor, welche z.B. der Planetenbewegung galten, waren aber nicht in der Lage, erklärende Theorien zu entwickeln. Erste Beispiele angewandter Physik stammen vom griechischen Mathematiker Archimedes, welcher auf diesem Wege beispielsweise Hebel und Schrauben konstruierte. Erst im 17. Jahrhundert führten experimentelle Methoden und wissenschaftliche Messgeräte zu einem fundierten Verständnis vieler grundlegender physikalischer Gesetze. In dieser Zeit begannen Wissenschaftler wie Johannes Kepler und Sir Isaac Newton, die Theorien der antiken griechischen Philosophen zu untersuchen und oftmals zu widerlegen, indem sie neue Theorien der physikalischen Gesetzmäßigkeiten formulierten und auf wissenschaftlichem Wege belegten. Entdeckungen auf dem Gebiet der Physik führen selten zu direkten Anwendungen - sie helfen aber beim grundlegenden Verständnis der prägenden Gesetze des Universums und legen so Fundamente für praktische technologische Fortschritte.
TEXT.Italian: La fisica è lo studio delle forme di materia e di energia e del modo in cui queste interagiscono tra loro. Alcune popolazioni antiche osservarono alcuni fenomeni fisici, come il moto planetario, ma non furono in grado né di scoprirne le cause, né di formulare delle teorie al riguardo. Alcune delle prime applicazioni della fisica si devono al matematico greco Archimede, il quale inventò dei dispositivi come le leve e le viti. Solo agli inizi del XVII secolo, i metodi sperimentali e gli strumenti scientifici di misurazione consentirono di comprendere le leggi fisiche e scienziati come Keplero e Isaac Newton iniziarono a confutare le teorie degli antichi filosofi greci e a dimostrare scientificamente la veridicità delle proprie teorie. Nella fisica, le scoperte hanno raramente un'applicazione diretta; tuttavia, migliorano la comprensione delle leggi che governano l'Universo, costituendo così le basi del progresso tecnologico.
TEXT.Spanish: La física es el estudio de las numerosas formas de materia y energía y del modo en que éstas interactúan consigo mismas y entre sí. Varios pueblos de la Antigüedad hicieron observaciones acerca de ciertos aspectos de la física, como el movimiento planetario, pero fueron incapaces de desarrollar teorías acerca de las razones que explicaban estos fenómenos. Algunas de las primeras aplicaciones de la física fueron obra del matemático griego Arquímedes, que la utilizó para crear inventos como la palanca y el tornillo. No fue hasta el siglo XVII que los métodos experimentales y los instrumentos científicos de medición condujeron a una auténtica comprensión de las leyes fundamentales de la física. Algunos pioneros de la ciencia, como Johannes Kepler y sir Isaac Newton comenzaron a refutar las teorías de los filósofos de la Grecia antigua y demostrar científicamente las postuladas por ellos mismos sobre las leyes de la física. Los descubrimientos en física rara vez tienen aplicación directa, pero en cambio proporcionan una visión básica de las leyes que rigen el universo y forman la base sobre la que se sustentan los avances tecnológicos.

TEXT.English: "To every action there is always opposed an equal reaction." - Isaac Newton
TEXT.French: "A chaque action correspond une réaction égale." - Isaac Newton
TEXT.German: "Jede Aktion erzeugt gleichzeitig eine gleichwertige Reaktion." - Isaac Newton (1643-1727)
TEXT.Italian: "Ad ogni azione, corrisponde una reazione uguale ma di segno opposto." - Isaac Newton
TEXT.Spanish: "Para cada acción existe siempre una reacción igual y de sentido contrario." - Isaac Newton

TEXT.English: The first civilization to discover Physics receives a Great Scientist. It also enables Skyscrapers (with Civil Engineering and Steel) improvement and the World Wonder Isaac Newton's College.
TEXT.French: La première civilisation à découvrir la physique reçoit un Savant Illustre. Il permet également d'améliorer les gratte-ciel (avec Civil Ingénierie et Acier) et la Merveille mondiale Collège d'Isaac Newton.
TEXT.Spanish: La primera civilización en descubrir la Física recibirá un Gran científico. También permite construir Rascacielos (con la Ingeniería civil y el Acero) y la gran maravilla del Colegio de Isaac Newton.

TEXT.English: Picotechnology
TEXT.French: Picotechnologie

TEXT.English: It is a hypothetical future level of technological manipulation of matter, on the scale of trillionths of a meter or picoscale (10^-12). This is three orders of magnitude smaller than a nanometer (and thus most nanotechnology) and two orders of magnitude smaller than most chemistry transformations and measurements. Picotechnology would involve the manipulation of matter at the atomic level. A further hypothetical development, femtotechnology, would involve working with matter at the subatomic level.
"The whole edifice of modern physics is built up on the fundamental hypothesis of the atomic or molecular constitution of matter."[NEWLINE][SPACE] -C.V. Raman
TEXT.French: "Tout l'édifice de la physique moderne est construit sur l'hypothèse fondamentale de la constitution atomique ou moléculaire de la matière."[NEWLINE][SPACE] -C.V. Raman

TEXT.English: TBD
Pictographs
TEXT.French: Pictographes
TEXT.Polish: Piktografiki

TEXT.English: A pictogram is an ideogram that conveys its meaning through its pictorial resemblance to a physical object. Pictographs are often used in writing and graphic systems in which the characters are to a considerable extent pictorial. A pictogram may also be used in subjects such as leisure, tourism, and geography.[PARAGRAPH:2]Pictography is a form of writing which uses representational, pictorial drawings, similarly to cuneiform and, to some extent, hieroglyphic writing, which also uses drawings as phonetic letters or determinative rhymes. Some pictograms, such as Hazards pictograms, are elements of formal languages.[PARAGRAPH:2]Pictograph has a rather different meaning in the field of prehistoric art, including recent art by traditional societies and then means art painted on rock surfaces, as opposed to petroglyphs; the latter are carved or incised. Such images may or may not be considered pictograms in the general sense.
TEXT.Polish: Piktogram (łc. pictus - narysowany - pismo) - przedstawienie pojęcia (opisywanego wyrazem bądź równoważnikiem zdania) za pomocą obrazka w oderwaniu od zapisu. Piktogramami są np. hieroglify, znaki drogowe i ostrzegawcze, oznaczenia przeciwpożarowe. Formą piktogramu jest również ideogram. Piktogram pełni ważną funkcję w komunikacji. Dzięki zastąpieniu słowa pisanego elementem graficznym zwiększono czytelność przekazu oraz ominięto barierę językową. Użycie piktogramów ułatwia też wspomaganie mowy osób upośledzonych i z trudnościami w porozumiewaniu się.

TEXT.English: I put my hand on the dark skin and felt the chill of centuries long gone. It was as if I had touched the Stone Age.[PARAGRAPH:2]- Nikolai Vereshchagin,[PARAGRAPH:1][SPACE][SPACE]"Boy's Life (April 1981)"
TEXT.French: "Je mis ma main sur la peau sombre et senti le froid des longs siècles passés. C'était comme si j'avais touché l'âge de pierre." - Nikolai Vereshchagin
TEXT.Polish: "Położyłem moją dłoń na czarnej skórze i poczułem chłód wszystkich tych wieków, które przmineły. To tak jakbym dotknął epoki kamienia." - Nikolai Vereshchagin

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Pictographs[COLOR_REVERT] is a prehistoric era technology that unlocks the construction of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Rock Art[COLOR_REVERT] building which gives [ICON_CULTURE][COLOR_GREEN]Culture[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_GREEN]Research[COLOR_REVERT].
